search_result.title: Quentin Miller as sheriff sees Buncombe joining jail diversion ...
search_result.text:
ASHEVILLE — In its new sheriff, Buncombe County might have found its best hope in forestalling, if not eliminating, the need for building a new jail — a project that would come with a multi-million price tag and a host of ancillary costs.

For the better part of two years, the Buncombe District Attorney Todd Williams has been preaching the efficacy of diversion programs, but he's lacked a congregation.

Current Sheriff Van Duncan expressed interest in diversion programs, but he thought the county lacked the resources needed to pull one off. The retiring sheriff also didn't want to shoulder a future sheriff with a program that he or she might not want, he told the Citizen Times recently.

Williams could never secure buy-in from outgoing Asheville Police Chief Tammy Hooper either, he said. She recently announced her resignation, effective Jan. 2.

"I think once we get one of those big law enforcement agencies on board, I would hope that other agencies would have no problem," Williams said before Tuesday's election. "Hopefully, we'll see somebody step up who wants to approach these problems in a new way."

Enter Quentin Miller.

By a resounding margin, the county chose Miller, a 25-year veteran of the Asheville Police Department, to helm the sheriff's office after Duncan retires at the end of November. And Miller, unlike either of his opponents in the heated race, has long touted the need for alternatives to incarceration.

"It may sound crazy, but in order for us to help some people, we can't always incarcerate them," Miller told the Citizen Times in an interview Thursday. "We're willing to try something different so long as people are still safe."

What is diversion?

Pre-charge diversion programs, such as Seattle's Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion, offer low-level offenders — namely drug addicts arrested for possession or small property crimes — an option: treatment or time in a cell.

More serious offenders, those charged with felonies or suspected of committing violent crimes, are not eligible for diversion.

LEAD, which law enforcement started in King County, Washington, in 2011, has since received nationwide attention. The program has been replicated or otherwise outsourced to cities and counties across the nation, including in North Carolina.

Fayetteville, Wilmington and even Waynesville have adopted LEAD-styled programs, hoping to get at one of the main causes of criminality in the era of mass opioid dependency: addiction.

Recognizing what he sees as the potential of these programs, North Carolina Attorney General Josh Stein has been holding statewide, roundtable meetings about pretrial diversion options for the past year and a half. Williams was the only district attorney to attend a recent such meeting, which was held in Raleigh on Oct. 29.

Stein told the Citizen Times that he's interested in pre-charge diversion programs because he believes they have a better shot at reducing drug dependency than simply locking addicts away.

"The physical urge to get heroin in their body is so strong that they will do almost anything to get the money to buy drugs; that's the cycle we have to break," Stein said, describing why drug addiction and small property crime often go hand in hand.

"If we want to address the criminality of people who use drugs, the most effective thing we can do is break them of their chemical dependency."

Buncombe County already offers a host of post-charge diversion options.

Prosecutors can elect not to pursue cases against people who choose to seek treatment though a venue like the county's Drug Treatment Court. But post-charge diversion does little to address fact that there are currently some 370 inmates the Buncombe County Detention Facility currently being held awaiting trial. The jail holds about 600 people.

"Diversion programs will give us the opportunity to divert people coming into the justice system and to get those people help," Miller said. "They allow law enforcement to divert people away from jail before they ever hit the system."

Miller said that he wouldn't support the diversion of violent offenders, those accused of committing sex crimes or people suspected of committing crimes against children.

The cost of a charge

Charges alone can be life altering for people. Charges — even without convictions — can disqualify people from employment. And they can derail families financially as posting bail can be expensive.

"Just having an arrest record has collateral consequences," said Williams, who as a prosecutor knows this better than many people. "That's why a LEAD-style program is the next step of the evolution of diversion in Buncombe County."

Miller said he'd have to speak with his deputies and take community advice before he committed to any pre-charge diversion program, but he shares Williams' concerns. He also recognizes another harsh reality of the status quo.

“Charges don’t stop you from taking up bed space in the jail either,” Miller said.

As the county grows and as the number of open beds in the jail shrinks, this is worthy of concern, Miller said. And he's not the only person who thinks so.

County Commissioner Jasmine Beach-Ferrara told the Citizen Times she remembers discussions about building a new jail from the winter of 2016, shortly after she was elected.

"Forty-seven million dollars was the price tag that we heard about building a new jail," she said. "These are very real questions, and we need to look at every option and solution."

Though those conversations ended without the county committing any funding to a new facility, Beach-Ferrara said, that discussion is likely not over. In an October interview, Duncan told the Citizen Times that the 604-bed jail typically holds close to 590 inmates on any given day.

A $47 million price tag is high, but Stein shared a few more numbers that he finds relevant to discussions about incarceration. It costs about $100 a day to keep somebody in jail in North Carolina, and the state spends about $32,000 a year to hold people in prison.

"This is not a cost-effective way to treat people's illnesses," he said.

Big changes in Buncombe County

One of Duncan's biggest hang-ups when asked about pre-charge diversions was cost.

Nobody yet knows exactly what a pre-charge diversion program in Buncombe County would look like, so it's hard to say how one might affect the sheriff's bottom line.

Williams and Miller both said that the community — including law enforcement officers, attorneys and judges — would need to weigh in before any program was put in place. The powers that be would need to decide who would be eligible for diversion and how such a program would work.

Electing a sheriff that is interested in pursuing pre-charge diversion was just the first step, Williams said.

But the $1.75 million MacArthur grant recently awarded to Buncombe County with the goal of reducing the jail population should certainly help ease financial concerns.

The grant is part of a $148 million national initiative known as the Safety and Justice Challenge, which aims "to reduce over-incarceration by changing the way America thinks about and uses jails," the county wrote in a press release announcing the grant late last month.

The Justice Resource Advisory Council, of which Williams is a member, will help advise the county when it comes time to allocate the $1.75 million award. Williams said that diversion programs would go a long way toward helping the county move toward the goal of the grant.

Miller has been meeting with Williams and others in others in the criminal justice system for months to discuss diversion options. The most important consideration in determining whether such programs will become reality in Buncombe is whether the community is ready, he said.

"A lot of has to do with the community and with officers' buy-in," Miller said. "I've talked about changing the mindset from being warriors to guardians. This is going to be the test. The mindset has been 'lock 'em up, lock 'em up, lock 'em up' and I was that way, too. But we've got to change."

search_result.title: Loitering, panhandling can get you banned from Wilmington
search_result.text:
This story has been updated to reflect the changed narrative regarding the stabbing death of a woman in Baltimore.

Nineteen-year-old Isiah Barnett was standing at a Wilmington bus stop on a November afternoon when a police officer told him he was under arrest.

The crime, according to police, was his presence in downtown Wilmington.

Twelve days before, Barnett had been banned from the city's business district. A justice of the peace ordered his exile from the 40-square-block area around Market Street on Oct. 25.

It was a condition of his bail for charges of "aggressively" panhandling and resisting arrest, records show. Barnett said he asked a friend for money — panhandling itself is not illegal — and walked away from a police officer.

The teen is one of at least a half-dozen people accused of nonviolent, minor crimes who have been ordered to have no contact with large areas of Wilmington as a condition of their release from jail, The News Journal has learned.

Some defendants awaiting trial for low-level crimes like loitering, aggressive panhandling and disorderly conduct have been banished from the entire city.

"It’s outrageous," said Dan Atkins, executive director of the Community Legal Aid Society, Inc. "Poverty is unpleasant. The solution to it isn’t to protect ourselves from it by pretending that it doesn't exist."

No-contact orders are a standard way to keep accused perpetrators of crimes away from their victims during the course of a criminal case, said retired Wilmington police officer Dan Selekman.

The restrictions, typically requested by police and approved by a justice of the peace, can prohibit a drug dealer from returning to their area of business or a domestic abuser from visiting their alleged victim between bail and sentencing.

"It's usually related to someone who is causing a tremendous amount of issues," he said.

The little-known use of broad bans for minor crimes, which experts said is unusual and ineffective, is supported by Wilmington Police, Mayor Mike Purzycki and at least some downtown business leaders.

They are being issued here as cities nationwide grapple with how to handle complaints of panhandling.

Laws against aggressive begging were passed recently by officials in Erie, Pennsylvania and Ocala, Florida; the mayor of Indianapolis invested $500,000 last month in police and services to curb panhandling; and a Maryland man called for a panhandling crackdown after he claimed his wife was fatally stabbed while trying to give someone money in Baltimore. Police and prosecutors later said the man was responsible for his wife’s death.

Selekman said the purpose of no-contact orders, in general, is to protect the victims.

'"It’s (the court's) responsibility to make sure the victim doesn’t get revictimized," he said.

In Barnett's case, the victim named in court records was "society."

Criminalizing poverty?

While pre-trial geographic restrictions are not new in Delaware, the breadth of the orders issued for minor, poverty-related crimes has raised eyebrows in Wilmington criminal justice circles in recent weeks.

Local and national experts in the rights of the poor said it's unusual and inhumane to ban people — some of whom are likely homeless, addicted to substances or mentally ill — from Wilmington, which is a hub of social services.

"I see no evidence that people can comply with them," said Katherine Beckett, a University of Washington sociology professor.

Beckett wrote a book called "Banished: The New Social Control In Urban America" about the tactics governments use to quietly remove "unwanted" people from public spaces. In her research, she has not seen the type of no-contact orders being used in Wilmington. Similar methods perpetuate incarceration, she said.

"What you get is the person is cycling in and out of jail more than they would otherwise," she said. "It’s not a long-term solution. It's not even a short-term solution."

Assistant Public Defender Meryem Dede represents Barnett and has witnessed three others facing vagrancy-related charges who were ordered not to enter Wilmington city limits at all until the conclusion of their cases.

Those people, who she cannot name due to confidentiality obligations, have faced charges for some combination of aggressive panhandling, resisting arrest, loitering, disorderly conduct and noncompliance with their bond.

She said the no-contact orders cause hardship for clients experiencing homelessness.

"We don’t have shelters that are outside the city but are still close enough that you could make an 8:30 a.m. trial," she said.

Violation of a no-contact order is punishable by up to a year in jail, Dede said.

The News Journal requested records from the city, state and the court system to gain an understanding of how many defendants are banned from Wilmington and municipalities throughout Delaware via pre-trial no-contact orders. It did not receive the information by publication.

Wilmington PD apologizes after advising people to ignore 'aggressive panhandlers'

Tina Showalter, a former Delaware prosecutor, said the no-contact orders she saw in her career with the Department of Justice were specific, such as prohibiting contact with a victim or place of business.

Even in cases involving drug trafficking or a large criminal enterprise, Showalter said she isn't aware of anyone banned from an entire city.

"They were related to the subject of the underlying offense and structured by the court in a defined way," she said.

Department of Justice prosecutors are not involved at Justice of the Peace Court in the setting of bail in low-level offenses like loitering and aggressive panhandling.

When a News Journal reporter met Barnett in Wilmington on Nov. 29, he was not aware that his no-contact order was in place but said such restrictions would not be realistic for him because "I got family up here."

Barnett, who said he lives in Wilmington but whose court records state his residence is in Maryland, could not be reached for further comment.

Not a new practice

Police Chief Robert Tracy said geographic restrictions have been used for decades but the department renewed its interest in the method about a year ago.

Public and private officials with an interest in tempering loitering and panhandling got together in November 2017.

The attendees were Justice of the Peace Court Chief Magistrate Alan Davis; Deputy Attorney General A.J. Roop; a Wilmington police officer; a representative of a local college; the deputy director of Downtown Visions, a nonprofit that promotes business interests; and a representative of Buccini/Pollin Group, Wilmington's largest developer, according to Davis.

The parties talked about complaints from downtown businesses regarding panhandling and loitering, Davis said. No-contact orders were discussed as a tool for combating these issues, said Downtown Visions Deputy Director Michael Maggitti.

The police representative expressed that the department should pursue geographic restrictions more often and would recommend it to the officers, according to Maggitti.

BPG co-founder Rob Buccini could not be reached for comment.

After the meeting, Davis said he relayed the business district's concerns to judges he oversees. He said that he did not make any directive to increase the use of geographic no-contact orders for vagrancy-related offenses.

"No one is under any order to put restrictions in place," he said.

According to Davis, the practice is "thoughtfully done."

"If somebody presents a significant risk that they’re going to re-offend in that area, a geographical restriction is not a bad idea," he said. "Obviously, you want to tailor them as closely as you can."

Tracy couldn't say on Tuesday how many people are currently banned from parts or all of the city or whether the increased awareness of no-contact orders as a tool has resulted in more of them being issued.

He promised to research the question but said the citywide orders are rare.

Wilmington police chief says 'no new trend' in aggressive panhandling

Tracy recalled a sergeant told him that in one six-month period in 2017, about 15 people were banned from downtown Wilmington as a bail condition for various alleged crimes.

As for effectiveness in reducing crime, Tracy said the no-contact orders require "a longer study."

"Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn’t," he said.

The chief said he hadn't heard of the practice until he was briefed on the November 2017 meeting but has since incorporated the concept into his Compstat meetings. When an officer shares information about a habitual offender, Tracy asks: Have we sought geographic restrictions?

It's not illegal to simply ask for money or hold a sign soliciting donations. Tracy said police are not targeting people who conduct themselves without bothering or harassing others.

"We're not doing it unnecessarily because people are poor," he said. "You can ask for money. No one is stopping that. It’s the behavior surrounding it."

For Tracy, no-contact orders are tools that help assuage the concerns of people who report alarming or menacing behavior by panhandlers.

"People are asking us what we're doing about it, and we’re trying to appeal to all needs of the community," he said. "It’s a delicate balance."

Tracy emphasized that the orders are not unilateral decisions made by cops. They are approved by justices of the peace, he said.

Officers must demonstrate to the justice that the defendant does not live or work in the area and is there "for no other purpose than to commit a crime," according to Tracy.

In Delaware, justices of the peace are not required to be lawyers. Some are not.

Defendants sign off on the order to confirm they understand the conditions, Tracy said. If the restriction would limit their ability to visit their lawyer, doctor or social service provider, they may tell the justice, Tracy said.

Legal questions

Beyond moral and practical concerns, the use of broad no-contact orders may be unconstitutional, according to American Civil Liberties Union Legal Director Ryan Tack-Hooper.

"It’s an excessive and unreasonable condition of bail," Tack-Hooper said, noting the issues raises First Amendment issues and other legal questions.

The purpose of bail, as defined by law, is to protect public safety and ensure the defendant shows up to court. Showalter said banning a person from part or all of the city does neither.

"Are you trying to protect the community or are you just trying to kick someone out of that location?" said Showalter, who heads Housing Alliance Delaware, which connects homeless people with shelter.

Eric Tars, senior attorney with the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty in Washington D.C., said he hasn't seen other jurisdictions use geographic no-contact orders like they're being utilized in Wilmington.

The practice, he said, is "ridiculous."

Pushing poor people out of the city may be more politically expedient than investing in solving the root causes of poverty, Tars said, but it's counterproductive.

"If cities expended half the energy on looking for creative solutions than constitutional loopholes to continue enforcing these criminalization approaches, we’d be much further ahead," he said. "But unfortunately that's where they do put all of their energy."

Tars pointed to Philadelphia's Hub of Hope as a model of how a city can tackle issues of homelessness head-on. Since 2012, the walk-in engagement center in Suburban Station has served as a place to get coffee, take a shower, wash laundry and connect with case managers who can help clients find treatment programs and permanent housing.

"The best approach is not to force those people to go somewhere else but give them a better choice," he said. "Nine times out of 10, they will take that better option."

Asked for an interview, Purzycki's office instead offered an emailed statement in which he stood by the use of the no-contact orders.

“These restrictions are court-ordered," he said. "There are times when a record of crime, aggressive behavior or repeated offenses warrant certain restrictions. I trust the judgment of the courts and the Wilmington Police Department to do what is right to protect the public and protect the rights of individuals."

According to Selekman, when it comes to loitering and panhandling, broad geographic no-contact orders don't benefit anyone.

"You can pump them out into the county, but they’re still homeless, and they may have drug or alcohol addiction," he said. "They’re still in need of whatever that service is. That's the inhumane part. That’s the worst thing you could do for someone."

search_result.title: Bill to legalize marijuana in Delaware fails in House
search_result.text:
Delaware will not become the 10th state to fully legalize marijuana — at least not this year.

The House on Wednesday defeated a bill that would have created a taxable industry dedicated to the production and sale of legal cannabis.

The measure fell four votes shy of the 25 needed to move the bill to the state Senate. The final vote was 21-15 with five lawmakers — all Democrats — opting not to vote at all.

The defeat marked the end of a nearly two-year effort to join states such as Colorado and California in legalizing the drug for use by adults 21 and older.

"We're devastated that the House of Representatives would vote against this citizen-led effort ... and vote in favor of allowing the criminal market to control the most lucrative cash drop in Delaware," said Zoe Patchell, head of the Delaware Cannabis Advocacy Network and the leading voice of the legalization movement here.

For co-sponsors Rep. Helene Keeley, D-Wilmington, and Sen. Margaret Rose Henry, D-Wilmington, the vote also signifies the end of a long crusade to reform Delaware's marijuana laws. Both women are retiring at the end of their current term.

Together, they sponsored legislation that in 2011 created the state's medical marijuana program and a 2015 decriminalization law that downgraded possession of an ounce or less from a criminal offense to a civil violation, like a parking ticket.

"Of course I wanted to be able to go out on a good note," Keeley said after the vote on full legalization. "I'm a little sad I couldn't get it done. I couldn't get it over the goal line."

Advocates for full legalization have faced steep opposition since the bill was introduced in early 2017.

Despite meeting with marijuana advocates, Gov. John Carney repeatedly said he was not in favor of House Bill 110, arguing that more time is needed to study the full impact of marijuana legalization elsewhere.

The Delaware Marijuana Control Act also was condemned by a coalition of influential organizations that represent police, hospitals, doctors and some of the state's largest employers.

Led by AAA Mid-Atlantic, those groups argue that legalizing cannabis will result in a surge of drugged-driving crashes, emergency room visits, drug addiction and children being exposed to marijuana.

"We believe the final vote reflects the necessary caution before any major public policy change," said Cathy Rossi, vice president of public and government affairs for the Delaware-based car club. "From a road safety perspective, we want Delaware drivers, passengers, bicyclists and pedestrians spared the increased risk of marijuana-impaired drivers that states like Colorado and Washington are now facing.”

In explaining their opposition, several Republican lawmakers cited various statistics — ranging from increased drugged driving to spikes in infant exposure — from states where marijuana has been legalized.

But Keeley said the concerns raised behind closed doors by her fellow Democrats — who ultimately decided the outcome — centered on the opposition of law enforcement groups such as the Delaware Police Chiefs' Council.

Rep. Trey Paradee, D-Cheswold, said those opposed to the legislation are on the wrong side of history, noting that 61 percent of state residents support legalization according to a 2016 poll conducted by the University of Delaware.

"This bill is going to pass," he said. "Maybe not tonight but it is inevitable."

Advocates had attempted to counter resistance to the bill by arguing legalization would largely replace what is now a criminal industry with a legal one that could yield more than $20 million a year in tax revenue.

Tax dollars raised by the legal industry would have been directed toward education, helping prisoners re-enter society, drug abuse rehabilitation and prevention programs and initiatives aimed at training police officers to recognize whether drivers are under the influence of marijuana and other drugs.

House Bill 110 also would have created a commission to regulate, license and tax the state's marijuana business, which could have included as many as 40 retail stores, along with growing operations and testing facilities. The state's three medical marijuana

dispensaries would have been given the first opportunity to open retail operations.

Introduced in March 2017, the legislation managed to get out of committee last year but failed to get a vote on the House floor.

That led Keeley and Henry to create a 25-member task force that spent seven months studying how the state might regulate a legal marijuana industry. The hope was that the final report from the panel — made up of legalization proponents, opponents and representatives from various state agencies — might help sway undecided or uncommitted legislators.

Instead, the task force ended in confusion and controversy with members refusing to endorse the final product.

That did not stop Keeley from using the task force's report to write an amendment that sought to address many of their concerns, while also reducing the total vote count needed for passage.

The prior threshold was set by the addition of new criminal penalties related to fines for underage consumption while the new version relies on existing laws to accomplish the same goal.

That change was not enough to secure the bill's passage, however. The amendment still required support from a three-fifths super-majority due to the new fees it created for licensing cannabis-related businesses.

"If it had been a simple majority, it would have passed," Patchell said. "This is absolutely inevitable and we're going to continue our efforts to replace the dangerous, criminal market for cannabis with a legal, taxed and well-regulated system."

search_result.title: DART restores some Rodney Square bus routes, not enough for riders
search_result.text:
The Delaware Transit Corp. announced on Wednesday that it will return three bus routes to Rodney Square in Wilmington but is rejecting public demands to restore all stops to the former transportation hub.

DART said it reviewed customer feedback from three public meetings and decided to "make a series of improvements," according to a press release.

Starting Sunday, the Rodney Square bus stop on 10th Street will service routes 2, 6 and 28. But the other 10 routes that were removed from the square will stay that way, scattered around downtown, DART said.

Gov. John Carney indicated the dismantling of the hub in December will help restore Rodney Square as the "crown jewel of Wilmington."

“The success of our state depends in large part on the success of Wilmington,” Carney said in a statement. "We must continue the work to revitalize the Square as a historic public park. We’re continuing to make improvements to our transit system that balance the needs of riders and those who use Rodney Square.”

BACKGROUND:Bus riders clash with DART over elimination of Rodney Square stops

Route 6 runs from Wilmington to Newark. Route 2 travels from the Amtrak station up Concord Pike to the Concord Mall and Brandywine Town Center, and Route 28 goes from Amtrak through Trolley Square to Nemours/A.I. duPont Hospital for Children.

Riders and their advocates have complained for weeks at public meetings and in dozens of calls to the Governor's Office since Dec. 17 when changes took effect. On Wednesday night, about two dozen city residents spoke at a City Council committee meeting to demand the routes revert back to the way they were.

"This is a travesty of justice," said Tasmania Wootson, a disabled grandmother of eight who described a scary walk home from her new stop. "It is dark. There is no complete lighting. There is no police protection around."

Opponents to the changes are concerned about elderly and disabled riders who struggle to walk the distance to new connections. They are also confused about new routes, aggravated that some of the new stops lack benches and shelters and bothered that they feel there was no reason to change the routes in the first place.

DART CEO John Sission said the changes were meant to reduce congestion but also to satisfy the visions Carney and Mayor Mike Purzycki have for the square.

Purzycki said in an email last week that he believes Rodney Square "can either be an aesthetically pleasing central square or it can be a congested bus hub."

Riders and their advocates, including state Rep. Charles Potter Jr. and Sen. Robert Marshall, say the government is valuing the interests of the businesses around Rodney Square more than the customers who patronize the bus system.

"We want to make Rodney Square great again?" said coalition member D. Marque Hall on Wednesday. "Come on now. These are people. ... We can't have public transportation. We got public discrimination."

Purzycki said in a statement on Thursday that his concerns about Rodney Square are "focused on the congestion caused by a large number of buses."

"We want to create a more beautiful town square that everyone can enjoy," he said. "Anyone who says or implies that my concerns or intentions go beyond this goal are ill-informed.”

Five City Council members sent a letter on Wednesday afternoon asking DART to make adjustments to appease riders. It did not request that Rodney Square become a bus hub again. According to the date on the letter, it was sent after DART had already drafted a press release about its latest adjustments.

Members of the public criticized the council on Wednesday for allegedly not advocating for them earlier.

"I am pissed off that this body did not put out a statement before time," said Jakim Mohammed, a member of the Coalition to Keep Bus Service on Rodney Square. "New Castle County Council, who I'm always beefing about, put out a statement."

Public commenter Deion Wilson called the council's response "weak" and "a disgrace," especially, he said, because many council members are black. The council cannot control DART, he said, but it can advocate for its residents. Instead, he said the council has been more concerned with "witch" prayers and emotional support animals than "real issues."

"You did nothing, and this is your city," he said. "When I vote, not one of you getting my vote."

Council members, included President Hanifa Shabazz and Councilwoman Michelle Harlee, defended themselves and emphasized DART is a state-level agency.

"We’ve made demands. They have answered to those demands," Shabazz said. "I think we’re doing a great job."

Scott Spencer, a longtime transit consultant and coalition member, said the state's updated changes are "minimal."

"It certainly does not address the widespread discrimination and disruption that people are suffering from," he said. "It certainly is good they're restoring some service, but it doesn't restore the convenience of the bus hub that was there."

Customers, especially those who are elderly or physically challenged, say they struggle to make connections that are several city blocks apart. Some of the transfers require an uphill walk.

"I'm disabled," said 49-year-old Jeffrey Cassidy, who walked uphill to catch a bus last week. "It's difficult because I've had a stroke and my balance is off so I've got to walk with a walker."

If riders miss their transfer bus, they can wait 30 minutes or sometimes an hour for the next bus — and some of the new stop locations lack bus shelters and benches.

City resident Robert Vesnaver used to travel out of Rodney Square. Last week, he caught a bus at a stop downtown that had no bench or shelter.

"If it snows or rains, you're getting soaked," he said as he stood in windy, 20-degree weather in a sweatshirt. "What can you do?"

In response to feedback, DART is adding benches to bus shelters on French Street at Eighth Street as well as 10th Street at Tatnall Street. Shelters and canopies are also being ordered for installation along King Street at 10th Street and at Ninth and Sixth streets.

Vesnaver said there has not been enough communication about the changes, and many riders are confused.

"They don't have no maps out here," he said.

Nothing compares to the convenience of having a central transit hub, Spencer said.

"Every transfer you needed to make was right there at Rodney Square," Spencer said. "Now you're left to fend for yourself in the city. It's the most disruptive change DART has made in their history."

DART is planning to build a replacement hub near the Amtrak station, but construction hasn't started. It won't be completed for at least two years. The opponents of the changes argue if the routes needed to change, officials should have waited until there was a new hub.

RELATED: Wilmingtonians resist 'discrimination' in transportation, housing

Spencer called DART's changes a "shameful sham." He also alleged "what DART did is illegal" because he said the public notices outlining changes did not precisely match the changes that were implemented.

"Federal Transit Administration guidelines say if you receive federal funds, you need to give the public proper, complete and accurate notice of service and route changes," said Spencer, who has worked in transportation for 40 years.

DART's marketing and public affairs officer, Julie Theyerl, said: "We disagree with Mr. Spencer’s allegations."

"DART’s website clearly showed the proposed routing and bus stops prior to public hearing workshops, and the notices stated proposed changes to downtown bus routing and stops," she said.

Theyerl sent The News Journal a public notice that was posted ahead of a Sept. 20 meeting. It alerted riders to "bus route and schedule changes" but makes no mention of Rodney Square.

Spencer believes DART violated laws that protect citizens' civil rights. U.S. Department of Transportation civil rights complaint forms were passed out at Wednesday's meeting at the request of Councilman Samuel L. Guy.

"There's no way to make this right other than to put the buses back in a centralized hub," Spencer said.

search_result.title: Peltz plan raises fears DuPont research hubs will be cut
search_result.text:
Jeff Mordock, and Maureen Milford

Wilmington

Activist investor Nelson Peltz says he will work to slash between $2 billion and $4 billion from DuPont Co. if he wins a proxy fight with the company and secures four seats on its board – including one for himself.

Peltz is coy on details, explaining he does not yet have inside knowledge to guide him on precisely where to cut. But many fear DuPont's celebrated research operations will be on the chopping block.

Delaware is home to two of DuPont's most vital scientific laboratories – The Experimental Station, a 150-acre campus on Route 141 in New Castle County, and the Stine Haskell Research Center along Elkton Road in Newark. Combined, the two facilities employ 3,100, many in high-paying research-driven positions.

Steve Isberg, an associate professor of finance at the University of Baltimore, said cuts to DuPont's research budget would have a devastating impact on the Delaware economy.

"There is a multiplier effect on the economy when you lose high-paying jobs," he said. "Those people will leave their high-income homes, impacting the housing community, which will then reverberate into the local consumer markets."

In a two-hour interview with The News Journal, Peltz and senior officials for his New York hedge fund Trian Fund Management did not comment about specific plans for the research operations.

"Research and development is an important element of DuPont's future success, but like the rest of the business it needs to be well-managed and produce acceptable returns," he said.

Arthur B. Winkleblack, former chief financial officer of H. J. Heinz Co. and one of Trian's four nominees for DuPont's board, said costs could be streamlined by developing products that will generate the most sales – and producing those products in markets they're consumed.

"We would rather have research and development closer to the consumer," Winkleblack said.

DuPont, which has market capitalization of $67 billion, operates in more than 90 countries with more than 150 research and development centers throughout the globe.

Its Experimental Station in Wilmington was built in 1903 and is the birthplace of the company's most important and profitable products – nylon, Kevlar, Tyvek and the world's first synthetic rubber, neoprene. Roughly 2,500 employees work at the 150-acre campus, including hundreds of PhDs.

Stine Haskell, with 600 employees, is growing. DuPont is building a $35 million soybean research facility in Newark that will include two state-of-the-art automated greenhouses. The project is expected to be completed in 2016, with room for future expansion.

Worldwide, DuPont employs 63,000 people. Its 7,000 Delaware employees constitute 11 percent of the state's workforce.

Gov. Jack Markell said a reduction in research and development would undermine the state's identity as a global science leader. He's worried about Peltz's plans to divide DuPont into separate companies.

"There is significant cross-pollination among the scientists working there," the governor said. "If you split DuPont in two, what happens to that cross-pollination? My gut tells me that it would not be positive."

Peltz also called for turning seven business units into two separate companies. Agriculture, nutrition and health and industrial biosciences would be split into one company. The remaining units, comprised of DuPont's cyclical, high-cash generating businesses, performance materials, safety and protection and electronics and communications, would become another single company.

Should Peltz win, what was once DuPont could be split into three independent units. The company has already decided to spin off its performance chemicals unit, Chemours, this summer.

Shareholders vote on nominees in the proxy fight on May 13, and a recent Wells Fargo analyst report predicted a loss for Peltz. The meeting, open only to DuPont stock owners, is scheduled for 8:30 a.m. at the chemical giant's headquarters at Chestnut Run Plaza.

John Roberts, an analyst at UBS Securities, said he has not seen any sound data to determine which side will win, but acknowledged that incumbents, or sitting companies, usually have the edge in proxy elections.

"This is like any other election process," he said. "Some vote for the incumbent and some vote for change."

Trian Chief Investment Officer Ed Garden argues it's been years since DuPont scored on a success innovation – a sign the company's research and development reputation is larger than its actions.

"It's clear something is wrong because there is no next nylon or Kevlar," he said. "We need to go on the inside and work with other board members to figure out why that is."

Parry Norling, who worked 16 years at the Experimental Station as a research manager, argues that DuPont's research and development efforts are functioning well, and are crucial to the company's long- and short-term success. Separating DuPont's business units could negatively impact the station, he said, because groups across multiple sectors collaborated to create new products such as the ink Hewlett-Packard sells for printers.

"You can't separate those units," Norling said. "Sometimes it was two units and someone from central research working as a three-way team."

The success of one unit can lead to a critical development for another unit, Norling added. For example, the printer ink innovation lead to the creation of a dye to color carpets.

Peltz has called for DuPont to increase its debt-to-equity ratio, arguing a modest amount of debt could help the company improve its earnings-per-share target. Competitor Monsanto Co. took a similar step last year.

Some analysts said the Trian proposal is flawed because it overlooks DuPont's standing as a global science leader. Products range from Mylar and fungicides to pharmaceuticals and bioscience products, creating an economic wake that includes numerous support businesses inside and outside Delaware.

Isberg, of the University of Baltimore, said "DuPont lives and dies by its research and development."

"It needs cash flow for its research efforts," he said. "If DuPont loads itself up with debt and another fixed-interest payment, that cannibalizes your ability to do future research and development."

Trian began gathering DuPont shares in the summer of 2013 when it disclosed the purchase of a 0.6 percent stake in the company. Since then, the hedge fund has amassed a 2.7 percent share of DuPont stock, estimated to be worth $1.8 billion. In September 2014, Trian sent a sharp letter to DuPont's board that lauded the company's decision to spin off its performance chemicals unit, Chemours, but demanded DuPont further divide the company into two distinct units.

Peltz said he tried for two years to work with the company to reduce spending and improve performance before he initiated the proxy war, but he was rebuffed by Lead Independent Director Alexander M. "Sandy" Cutler, who also is CEO of Eaton Corp., a power management company based in suburban Cleveland.

In February, Peltz met with DuPont Chief Executive Officer Ellen Kullman and Cutler to discuss a potential compromise. Under the agreement, DuPont would support Myers for its board if Trian agreed to back its investor slate. DuPont officials said Peltz walked away from the agreement because the company would not select him as the potential board member.

During his interview with The News Journal, Peltz said if DuPont does not want him on the board, he would be willing to step aside and let Garden, a proposed alternate nominee, take his seat.

Cutler said that a Trian nominee joining DuPont's board could have negative repercussions.

"People say, What harm can one director do?" Cutler said. "But this is a comprehensive attack on the leadership of DuPont's board with a present agenda to leverage the balance sheet and break up the company. We think it doesn't create value for shareholders."

Cutler denied that he campaigned to keep Peltz off the board. He said the board talked with the four Trian nominees and concluded they did not possess the skills needed for boardroom seats. Cutler called the proxy vote a "comprehensive attack on the leadership of DuPont with a present agenda to leverage the balance sheet and break up the company."

He said a new concern is that Peltz wants to have to up to 20 Trian employees act as analysts for the four new board members. Allowing non-board members to play a role in board decisions has the potential to run afoul of Securities & Exchange Commission regulations, Cutler said.

"Trian, in a sense, becomes shadow management" if the proxy vote goes its way, Cutler said. "The corporate governance model that comes with Trian is very inappropriate. Their proposal is littered with corporate governance conflicts of interest that are simply unacceptable."

DuPont says Trian's claims about lackluster growth are inaccurate. Kullman noted that their multi-year strategy has created a stronger company that delivered shareholder returns of 266 percent over the past six years she's been CEO, outperforming both the Standard & Poor's 500 and the company's proxy peers. Employees also benefited from stronger returns, she said.

"We are both a long-term and short-term company," Kullman said in an interview with The News Journal.

She claimed Peltz is focused on generating a short-term stock bump at the expense of DuPont's long-term growth. And she worries what would happen to the company down the road.

"Our long-term approach has helped us emerge stronger from the financial crisis," she said. "We've seen that strategy generate shareholder returns. The change has been hard in the short-term, but in the long-term it makes sense."

In February, she blasted Peltz's record with Chemtura, a manufacturer of flame-retardant plastics. Trian founding partner Edward Garden got a seat on Chemtura's board. Garden eventually resigned from the board in 2009 and Chemtura declared bankruptcy a few months later.

Former DuPont Chief Executive Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the former Apple Computer Inc. board chairman credited with helping to bring Steve Jobs back to the company, said he believes Kullman has developed a winning strategy.

Peltz, by contrast, is proposing to take the company in an unknown direction that "may or may not work," solely for the purpose of a short-term boost in the stock price, he said. Woolard finds distasteful the quick-turn approach employed by activist investors, noting that companies also have a responsibility to their communities and employees.

"To totally disrupt the company to get the stock price up in the short term, including laying off a lot of people, seems reckless and inappropriate," Woolard said. "I can't believe Trian is going to get a majority of shareholders to vote for it."

He praised the leadership of both Kullman and the board.

"I'm sure if Peltz's logic was compelling," he added, "the board and leadership would listen."

Peltz believes his overarching moves could elevate DuPont's stock price above $120 per share. On Friday, the stock traded at $71. As Peltz sees it, DuPont will become a leaner, stronger operation – and the benefits will trickle down to other business in the state.

If the company does not right its ship, Peltz said, its headquarters city of Wilmington, which has struggled in recent years to overcome its reputation for violent crime, will take another punch in the gut.

"If DuPont starts to grow, Wilmington will get better," Peltz said.

However, he criticized the company for assembling a hospitality portfolio created for the benefit of the employees and the community. In the wake of the Peltz proxy fight, the company in January sold The DuPont Theatre in downtown Wilmington to The Grand Opera House, a move that "represents a strategic and mutually beneficial business decision," Kullman said in a statement at the time.

Company officials later announced plans to move the entire company headquarters out of the DuPont Building at 10th and Market streets at Rodney Square, home to central offices since 1908. About 1,000 workers will be relocating to Chestnut Run Plaza at Lancaster Pike and Centre Road in July. The downtown space will then house offices for Chemours.

DuPont also is taking bids for sale or management of the Hotel du Pont and the DuPont Country Club, a source familiar with the process said. Three hotel parking lots also have been sold recently.

Another concern among Delawareans is the possibility that Peltz could cut DuPont retiree health benefits. DuPont has an estimated 81,000 retirees, 10,000 who call Delaware home.

There are no federal or state regulations prohibiting companies from eliminating or reducing retiree health care benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act, or ERISA, does not protect retiree health benefits. Retirees only recourse is a breach of contract claim under the 1974 federal statute.

Madan Joshi, a microbiologist who retired from DuPont in 2007, said a cut in retiree health care benefits could be "a big blow" for DuPont retirees who did not have high-paying jobs.

He also is concerned about current employees in their 50s who are nearing retirement. If Trian wins the proxy fight, he asked, would its board members push for cuts to retirement benefits of current employees?

"My concern is about people who are on the edge financially and in terms of their ability to retire," Joshi said. "These Trian people, their goal is not to make the company more productive and stabilize things. It's to get in and makes cuts, cash in and go somewhere else. That's what their track record is."

Peltz has not threatened to cut DuPont retirees health benefits, but his actions at ketchup maker H. J. Heinz Co. have local retirees worried. After two Trian candidates joined the board, Heinz stopped providing retirees with health insurance and created a reimbursement account. The company started with a $7,000 contribution the first year, but eventually lowered it to $3,500.

In March, a group of former DuPont employees discussed the possibility of filing a class action lawsuit if the company reduces or eliminates retiree health benefits. They have not yet spoken with an attorney about a potential case.

In a statement, Trian said its plan to improve DuPont's performance is the best way to protect retiree benefits.

"Trian's interests are fully aligned with those of DuPont's current and former employees, customers, stockholders and the Wilmington community," Carissa Felger, a spokeswoman for the hedge fund. "If elected, Trian's nominees will strive to help DuPont to always be in a position to honor its obligations to current and retired employees."

This proxy battle is unprecedented, the first in DuPont's 213-year history. Throughout the majority of its history, the company was controlled by the du Pont family. While there was a nasty public fight among family members from 1915 to 1918 over the sale of company stock, this is the first time DuPont has fended off an activist investor.

Peltz came to national attention in 1997 when one of his investment vehicles, Triarc Cos., acquired Snapple from Quaker Oats. Snapple was combined with other beverage brands and sold to Cadbury Schweppes in 2000.

He founded Trian in 2005, and within a year launched a proxy war for Heinz. He succeeded in placing two new directors, including himself, on the company's board.

Peltz pushed for cost-saving ideas that resulted in Heinz selling or shuttering 15 factories and reducing spending by $355 million. The leaner Heinz attracted a venture between Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and 3G Capital. The companies paid $28 billion, or $72.28 per share, in an April 2013 sale, generating a 20 percent return on investment for shareholders.

In 2008, Triarc merged with fast-food giant Wendy's. Peltz pushed the burger chain to sell Tim Horton's, an under-performing doughnut subsidiary. Wendy's also consolidated three marketing units into one and cut 375 corporate jobs in a series a moves that saved $100 million.

Garden said the goal was to eliminate unneeded spending and concentrate on core products.

"We are focused on driving growth while reducing oppressive bureaucracy," Garden said. "It is not just about cutting costs."

Winkleblack, the former Heinz official, disputes Cutler's view that Trian is looking to divide companies. Peltz waged a successful proxy battle with Heinz in 2006, and Winkleblack initially opposed Peltz's admittance to the company board of directors on similar grounds. When the dust settled, Winkleblack said, Peltz worked with the board and had success creating shareholder value.

"To Nelson's credit, he sat down with me after a bitter proxy war and said, 'Let's make money for shareholders,' " Winkleblack said.

Trian's Garden said the hedge fund wants to help reposition DuPont, to bring in new ideas and to help it make smart decisions. Trian officials have said DuPont is too tied to its science legacy and isn't creative enough.

"We are not dogmatic," Garden said. "What we are trying to do is facilitate a debate on why DuPont's business units are not best in class when it comes to sales growth and margins."

That view is fiercely opposed by DuPont officials, who hammer home the fact that shares have increased 266 percent since Kullman became chief executive in 2009.

The Peltz plan is fundamentally flawed, Kullman argued. Were DuPont to make all of the "functional and corporate costs" proposed by Trian, Kullman said, it would only total $2.8 billion – less than the $4 billion in fat Peltz believes to exist in the company.

"If we do all the cuts Peltz wants, we could not close the books," she said, adding later, "We are not an underperforming company."

Peltz's lack of details troubles Markell.

"How can I take comfort in words that are not backed up without a focused strategy?" the governor asked.

The question comes down to whether the company is performing as poorly as Peltz claims, said Roberts of UBS in New York. If that's the case, layoffs are inevitable regardless of the proxy war's outcome, he said.

"If Peltz is correct, those jobs are a matter of time," Roberts said. "If DuPont is not producing results, sooner or later something has to change and he could bring the change earlier rather than later."

Matt Arnold, an analyst with Edward Jones in St. Louis, said it's likely any staffing reductions will be spread across the entire portfolio.

"Job losses could not just be a Delaware situation, it could be an everywhere situation," Arnold said. "The heightened amount of scrutiny on costs could imply a headcount reduction across every element of the business all around the world."

Isberg predicted that no matter the outcome of the proxy vote, DuPont will change.

"The real question is not will some kind of restructuring happen," he said. "The real question is how is it going to happen. There has been too much attention paid to DuPont for the company not to do some kind of restructuring."

A sign that DuPont may consider structural reform came in February with the additions of Edward Breen and James Gallogly to the company's board.

Gallogly is former chairman and CEO of LyondellBassell Industries, a tightly integrated chemical company similar to DuPont. While guiding it out of bankruptcy, Gallogly resisted urges to separate LyondellBassell's business sectors.

Breen was chairman and CEO of security systems-maker Tyco International, where he faced his own battles for control of the company's board. Immediately upon being appointed CEO, Breen sought to replace Tyco's entire board of directors.

"The two new directors have worked in the area of restructuring," Isberg said. "To me, bringing those two directors say DuPont is going to do more house cleaning here."

In that respect, it's likely DuPont will continue feeling pressure to analyze core business operations even if Trian is not successful in gaining seats, Arnold said.

Asked about what DuPont will look like with himself and three other Trian board members, Peltz said he has the best interest of the company in mind – restoring the company to greatness.

"My career was not built on cutting costs," he said. "I don't believe you can cut your way into prosperity."

search_result.title: Wilmington bus riders continue fight for Rodney Square bus routes
search_result.text:
A month after a dozen Wilmington bus routes were diverted from their usual stops at Rodney Square, many riders say they are beyond frustrated.

They're concerned about elderly and disabled riders who struggle to walk several blocks to make their new connections.

They're confused about new routes and aggravated that some of the new stops lack benches or shelters to provide relief from snow and rain.

And they're especially bothered that they feel there was no reason to change the routes in the first place.

"What DART is doing is reprehensible," said Jackson Kirk Grimes, 47, a disabled veteran who relies on forearm crutches to walk. "How are we supposed to walk four or five blocks to catch buses in the winter, in or in the hot summer time?"

Several dozen riders and their advocates gathered at the Wilmington Public Library on Tuesday during two feedback sessions held by the Delaware Transit Corporation.

DART implemented changes in mid-December so that 13 bus routes no longer stop in the square, which has been a transit hub since 1992. The decision garnered opposition before it was made and has received criticism since.

There are some remaining lines that stop in the square, but only buses that travel outbound to suburbs like Newark and Hockessin or downstate to places like Dover and Odessa said John Flaherty, who leads the Coalition to Keep Bus Service on Rodney Square.

The organization said it has collected over 1,300 signatures opposing the changes.

DART designed the meeting as a quiet meet-and-greet for bus riders to weigh in on recent service changes. But Flaherty had other ideas.

He came armed with a wireless microphone and speaker that advocates used to voice their feelings to the room.

"There's no rhyme or reason for this," Flaherty said, adding that he feels the dismantling of a city's transit hub is an unusual and radical move. "I can't think of any other place in the country that's doing this."

RELATED: Wilmington officials kick off land bank, 'key' to new development

DART's main explanation for changing the routes is that it wanted to reduce "congestion and overcrowding."

The transit organization had attempted to remove buses from the area before but folded under public opposition to moving a hub to Shipley Street.

It decided to pursue the effort again after it received complaints from the downtown business community and had discussions with Gov. John Carney and Wilmington Mayor Mike Purzycki, said John Sisson, DART's chief executive officer.

"I believe that Rodney Square can either be an aesthetically pleasing central square or it can be a congested bus hub," Purzycki said in an email on Tuesday.

Rodney Square is surrounded by businesses like the Hotel DuPont, owned by the Buccini/Pollin Group, and the Young Conaway Stargatt & Taylor law firm.

Sisson said corporate interests "were a voice like anyone else’s voice," but several rider advocates expressed their skepticism about that.

"The governor and the mayor accommodated the corporate tenants around Rodney Square and didn't give sufficient consideration to the riders," said state Sen. Robert Marshall.

Flaherty has filed Freedom of Information Act requests for state officials' correspondence relating to Rodney Square. He hopes to learn more about how the decision was made.

DART insists it's all for the good of transportation.

Julie Theyerl, DART's marketing and public affairs officer, said many of the buses that used to drive south down King Street now use French and Shipley streets too.

"We expanded the transit footprint downtown," she said.

But some riders are confused about DART's reasoning.

"I didn't think it was congested," said DART customer Charles May, 67. "Rodney Square is perfect for buses."

There was no traffic study done to justify a response to congestion, Sisson said.

"It’s anecdotal and the idea that Rodney Square is a park and not a transit center," Sisson said.

Having it be both would not be ideal, according to Sisson.

"What happens when the bus operation works around the park, you create a certain level of congestion, the buses surround the park to the point that there are no sight lines, and there's a lot of activity like nuisance crimes," he said.

Those alleged nuisance crimes are "not necessarily" committed by riders, he said, but he believes the crowds invite panhandling, and the illegal sale of cigarettes and bus passes.

"The idea that there were so many people there attracted that element," Sisson said.

The DART official said he feels there would be less of that activity if Rodney Square were simply a park.

Coalition member D. Marque Hall, 30, said the changes are "strategic" and discriminatory because they disproportionately affect the poor, especially minorities.

"They're trying to appeal to people they want to buy apartments," he said. "It's reminiscent of the Jim Crow south... Just because we're poor, we're not desirable."

RELATED: Wilmingtonians resist 'discrimination' in transportation, housing

DART is planning the construction of a new Wilmington transit hub near the Amtrak station, but it won't be operational for at least another two years, Sisson said.

The transit organization could've waited to change routes until then, but it wanted to get buses out of the square sooner.

"Really the desire to restore Rodney Square to a park, the desire by the mayor and governor's office to do that, and make sure downtown is a safe and vibrant pace, was the driving force of making these moves when we did," Sisson said.

The governor's office has received approximately 50 calls about the route changes around Rodney Square since the changes took effect, said Communications Director Jonathan Starkey.

"The governor takes the concerns he has heard seriously, and DelDOT is hosting a series of community meetings to address any issues with the new routes that may be adversely impacting riders," Starkey said.

DART said it's listening to riders' stories and may make adjustments based on their experiences. For instance, several riders have complained about a lack of benches at new stops.

Theyerl said DART decided not to install benches at all new stops because nearby businesses and neighbors are sometimes bothered when vagrants sleep on them. But DART is willing to provide them if riders ask.

"We'll see if we get specific requests for it," she said, adding that a compromise could be installing benches with dividers that make sleeping on them difficult.

A public hearing on the bus route changes is scheduled for March, and permanent changes take effect in May.

But the reality is that the feedback will only go so far.

Absent extraordinary circumstances, Rodney Square as riders knew it is over. On Monday afternoon, the benches situated under the square's bus shelters sat empty.

"It is not our desire to return Rodney Square to a transit hub," Sisson said.
