search_result.title: Wilmington mayor's anti-blight effort hits roadblock
search_result.text:
A proposal by Wilmington's mayor that would empower the city to impose liens and sheriff sales on vacant and blighted properties failed to advance on Monday after city council members and residents expressed concerns.

The mayor and director of licenses and inspections insist it is not their intention to kick people out of their homes.

BACKGROUND: Efforts to reduce blight in Wilmington raise concerns

"We don't do it to anybody now," Mayor Mike Purzcki said on Monday. "Why would we do it later?"

But residents said they want more than a verbal promise that the city won't seize property it wants to develop over a code violation as minor as a broken window.

"There’s a lot of power given in this bill," said Brian O’Neill of the Greater Wilmington Housing Providers.

BONES:Rehoboth discovery may change Delaware history

HOMICIDE:Pry marks found on back door in Cool Spring homicide

At a council committee meeting attended by several dozen residents on Monday, council members voted to hold the legislation for further deliberation. The mayor hoped to have it passed by the end of December and implemented by April after an education campaign, but that timeline is no longer possible. It will be subject to another committee meeting before it goes for a full vote of the council.

It's a setback for the mayor, who called the legislation "the most important thing we’ve done since hiring a new police chief."

"It's critical that we get it passed," Purzycki said.

Community development and urban planning committee members Zanthia Oliver and Nnamdi Chukwuocha voted to advance the legislation to a full council vote, but they were overshadowed by Yolanda McCoy, Trippi Congo, Vash Turner and Chairwoman Rysheema Dixon, who hesitated to vote at all.

The legislation would convert housing code enforcement from a criminal to a civil matter. Cases that are currently argued in court for months could be resolved more quickly if the city had more control, officials said.

As is, tenants end up living in substandard apartments owned by disinterested landlords, Purzycki said.

"The investment strategy is you can buy these properties cheaply, patch them and paint them and get a renter in there," he said.

Allowing properties to remain in the hands of irresponsible owners hurts the city, said Jeffrey Starkey, commissioner of Wilmington's Department of Licenses and Inspections.

"(Blight) attracts loitering, drug activity, prostitution, you name it," he said.

The proposal would allow the city to eventually sell a property at sheriff's sale if the owner fails to pay fines for violations ranging from maintaining inadequate garbage containers to neglecting to fix damage to an exterior wall, the legislation states.

The rewritten code creates three classes of violations:

Class 1 violations would incur a fine of $100 and include failing to fix a broken window or repair a leaking toilet.

Class 2 violations would incur a fine of $250 and include failing to install smoke detectors, provide hot water or pay the vacant property fee.

Class 3 violations would incur a fine of $1,000 and include failing to fix bulging foundational walls.

Each week the problem isn't fixed would be a separate violation and additional fine. An unpaid fine automatically becomes a lien, which could form the basis of a sheriff's sale, the city said.

The legislation does not describe a timeline, a number of violations or a threshold of fines that would trigger a sheriff sale.

At Monday's meeting, Congo repeatedly asked Starkey about the circumstances in which a property would be taken to sheriff sale.

Starkey did not provide a clear answer.

"The goal is not to take people’s property," Starkey said.

Frank Robinson, a longtime Hilltop resident and homeowner, said his neighborhood has many abandoned properties that he is tired of looking at. But with this legislation, he worries the city will punish homeowners who are not able, physically or financially, to fix violations.

"When we pass bills like this it’s usually the disabled, poor and elderly who get caught up in this," he said.

The city's intentions may be good now, but what matters is what the legislation allows, Robinson said.

"Mr. Starkey is a wonderful guy, but if he leaves tomorrow, this law is still in place."

The court system currently provides an objective third party for adjudicating housing cases, said Robinson, president of the West Side Community Action Committee. Cutting the courts out of the process puts homeowners at a disadvantage, he said.

"If you have no recourse, it’s just like eminent domain, just using code violations," he said.

Purzycki said the "political pressure" that would come with pushing homeowners out would be unbearable, and it's simply "not going to happen." If the public wants his commitment not to pursue lawfully occupied homes, he said he will put it in writing.

"We have no intention of throwing a homeowner out of the street because they can’t take care of their house," he said. "I'm open to legislative steps to formalize that view."

The code changes were recommended in a 2014 report by the Center for Community Progress, a national nonprofit focused on eliminating vacant, abandoned and deteriorated properties.

It endorses a “Fix it Up, Pay it Up or Give it Up” approach: urge owners to comply with housing regulations, force persistent violators to pay outstanding taxes and code liens, and use liens to take the property away from the owner and transfer it to "a responsible party."

One suggested "responsible party" is a land bank, a quasi-government entity that acquires problem properties and packages them for sale. Prospective owners and developers get a clean slate -- meaning they can buy without taking on the years of debt the property accumulated.

The Wilmington Neighborhood Conservancy Land Bank was established in 2015, and the city began transferring properties to it in October, according to its website.

The criminal-to-civil bill is part of a package of legislation that has changed since its introduction in October.

It reinstates pre-rental inspections, which the mayor said stopped about a decade ago. Starkey said he will need additional manpower in the licenses and inspections department to do this, which the mayor said will need to be approved in the next budget cycle.

Initially, the law mandated that every seven days a violation goes uncorrected will warrant another fine which would double after 180 days and triple after a year. The city removed the doubling and tripling provision.

The city also proposed adjustments to the nuisance property program, which assigns points to properties based on evidence of nuisance behavior. To "better capture nuisance activity," enforcement action would be taken against properties accumulating 18 or more points within an 18-month period, instead of a 12-month period, according to a substitute ordinance.

Points can be given for a variety of reasons including violent acts on the property, noise violations, police calls for service and health code violations.

For properties that hit the point threshold, the city can close the building, revoke a business license and issue a criminal summons, the city code states.

STORY: Vacant houses continue to blight Wilmington

The city had initially suggested repealing mandatory landlord training that was passed by the previous city council. A substitute ordinance brings back the training, but only for first-time owners of rental dwellings.

Paul Calistro, president of the Cornerstone West Community Development Corporation, called the legislative package "a mixed bag."

He applauded the increased time in which a vacant property must be registered (from 45 days to six months) and said the city needs a housing code with "some teeth" to deal with unengaged, out-of-state landlords.

"For vacant, blighted properties that are unoccupied, it’s fine… It's helping people who live next door," he said. "But for those properties who are owner-occupied, I think we have to treat them differently."

search_result.title: Wilmington efforts to reduce blight raise concerns
search_result.text:
Owners of vacant and blighted properties in Wilmington would face increased fees and could lose their property to sheriff's sale if new regulations are approved by the City Council.

Mayor Mike Purzycki says these rules – contained in four pieces of legislation – will strengthen neighborhoods.

"I believe strongly that property owners who do not live up to their responsibilities should not be permitted to continue hindering Wilmington’s efforts to create better neighborhoods," he said this week.

Several community members expressed concern at a public meeting on Thursday. They worry the legislation would enable the city to use increased fines and liens to push poor people and minorities out of the city.

"I hope that you all will try to humanize some of these laws," said Harmon Carey, founder of the Afro-American Historical Society.

The biggest adjustment in the proposal would be changing housing code enforcement from a criminal to a civil matter. This would give the city power to eventually sell a person's home at sheriff's sale if the person fails to pay fines for violations ranging from maintaining inadequate garbage containers to neglecting to repair smoke damage after a fire, the legislation states.

The rewritten code creates three classes of violations:

Class 1 violations would incur a fine of $100 and include failing to fix a broken window or repair a leaking toilet.

Class 2 violations would incur a fine of $250 and include failing to install smoke detectors, provide hot water or pay the vacant property fee.

Class 3 violations would incur a fine of $1,000 and include failing to repair fire damage or fix bulging walls.

STORY: Vacant houses continue to blight Wilmington

Every seven days the violation goes uncorrected will warrant another fine. If a violation remains for 180 days, the fine will double, the legislation states. If a violation is still not fixed within a year, the fine will triple. An unpaid fine automatically becomes a lien, which could form the basis of a sheriff's sale, the city said.

The city said the new system would avoid the usual "labor-intensive, time-consuming" process in court.

"It could be six months or more before you get in the court, and then we have to worry about extensions," said Councilman Bud Freel, the legislation's sponsor. "We’re on a decline, and we cannot let that continue. We have to build these neighborhoods back up."

The District 8 representative introduced a bill to change the housing code from criminal to civil enforcement last year, but it never advanced, records show. It was inspired by a 2014 report on Wilmington from the Center for Community Progress.

The legislation would substantially increase fees for properties that have been vacant for several years. Currently, homes that are vacant for 10 years face a $5,000 fine plus an additional $500 for every year thereafter.

The rules would stay the same for homes that have been vacant for less than two years (there is no fee for less than one year), a $500 fee for between one and two years, and a $1,000 fee for between two and three years.

For homes that are vacant between three and four years, the fee would jump to $5,000. For properties vacant four to five years, the proposed fee is $10,000; for five to six years, $12,000; for six to seven years, $14,000; for seven to eight years, $16,000; and for eight years or more, $18,000 plus $2,000 for each additional year.

Failure to register a vacant property under the new legislation would cost the homeowner $2,500. The city now requires registration after a property is vacant for 45 consecutive days, but officials are proposing an extension to six months to allow owners a longer period to remedy a vacancy.

The city does not yet have a fiscal impact statement for this legislation, the Mayor's Office said.

There are approximately 1,650 vacant properties in Wilmington, and roughly 200 are owned by the city, the Mayor's Office said. The city-owned properties will be transferred to the Wilmington Neighborhood Conservancy Land Bank, through which buyers can purchase them without taking on the debt incurred before the land bank acquired them.

"(The land bank) will maintain those properties and hold them together for future projects whether it's to fix a single-family or redo a whole block," Freel said.

At the meeting, resident Alethea Smith-Tucker questioned the reasoning of fining homeowners — and potentially seizing their property only because it's vacant.

"You can have a vacant property and have it be well-maintained. Why is there a fee?" she said. "It's not a land bank. It's a land grab."

Former Councilwoman Maria Cabrera said existing and proposed laws are "predatory."

"I know it's not your intention to take homes away from these folks, but that's what's going to happen," she said. "I'm all about transformation, but not on the backs of people who can't afford to fix their property. I hope that's not true because that, to me, does sound like gentrification."

Pastor Lottie Lee Davis, who lives in Southbridge, said she is concerned about the impact the legislation will have on the black population, for whom she said the government has historically created obstacles to homeownership.

"It is an asset that builds wealth in our community and should not be lost," she said.

The city also proposed doubling the residential rental license fees, from $50 to $100 per unit, with a cap at $2,500. The increase would go into the general fund, Freel said, and would be used to support city code enforcement. The city currently charges $50 to individuals with one or two units and $120, plus $10 per unit, to those owning three or more units.

Someone with five units now pays $170. The new legislation would increase that to $500.

The $2,500 cap would not account for property owners who operate 25 units under different business entity names, L&I Commissioner Jeff Starkey confirmed at the meeting.

Per-unit fees would not change for banks, which currently pay $723; building and loan associations, which pay $361; condominiums, which pay $60; and several other business types. The increase is for "rental dwelling units" only.

Brian O'Neill of Greater Wilmington Housing Providers criticized the "inequitable distribution" and asked if landlords would be getting an additional service for their increased fee.

"In essence, this is another tax," he said.

Wilmington raised property taxes by 7.5 percent this year and increased water/sewer rates by 4 percent. Councilman Vash Turner said Wilmington is putting a "foot on the necks of constituents in this city."

"My colleagues need to pay attention, and my constituents need to pay attention to my colleagues who don’t pay attention," he said.

Scott Foster, a longtime resident and homeowner, said the increased fee will hamper investment in the city.

"Well, heck, why not invest in the county?" he said. "You’re gonna take that money to invest it in L&I to issue more tickets at $50 a crack?"

Davis, a city landlord, said the increase could mean rising rents.

"Any cost that is given to me, I'm going to have to transfer it to them," she said.

The city also proposed adjustments to the nuisance property program, which assigns points to properties based on evidence of nuisance behavior. The mayor proposed extending the time period wherein points can accumulate to "better capture nuisance activity affecting the public interest."

Enforcement action would be taken against properties accumulating 20 or more points within an 18-month period instead of the current standard of 18 or more points within a 12-month period. Points can be given for a variety of reasons including violent acts on the property, noise violations, police calls for service and health code violations.

For properties that hit the point threshold, the city can close the building, revoke a business license and issue a criminal summons, the city code states.

Carey, who owns a property in south Wilmington, said he has received instant tickets he feels were excessive and unfair. He wonders if businesses on Shipley Street downtown are treated the same.

"Are they getting tickets the way we are getting tickets in the black community? I don't think so," he said. "That’s how if someone wanted to close me down, they could easily do it."

The mayor's proposal includes repealing mandatory landlord training passed last year.

Sponsored by Cabrera, the law requires the city's roughly 2,700 landlords to complete a free, city-approved training course before obtaining or renewing a business license. Training was supposed to start last month, but the Purzycki administration did not budget for it.

The new legislation would eliminate the requirement for all landlords. Instead, the licenses and inspections commissioner could require training at the landlord's expense as a condition for the issuance of a provisional business license.

O'Neill thanked the council for the proposed change.

"It seems the pendulum swung back to something very reasonable," he said.

Cabrera defended her landlord training requirement, arguing that a bartender cannot serve a glass of wine without a certification, but nothing is required of landlords.

"You can come into the city of Wilmington, buy a property, rent it out, without any knowledge of how to be a good property owner and a good landlord," she said.

The Mayor's Office said it hopes the legislation passes in December. The city hopes to implement the plan by April 1, followed by an education campaign.

Purzycki said in a statement that the legislation and policy reforms will prevent properties from "destabilizing" neighborhoods.

“Blighted and vacant properties weaken neighborhoods, encourage criminal activity, inhibit economic development, undermine otherwise stable real estate markets and encourage irresponsible property owners to continue their detrimental behavior," he said.

The City Council will hold another public meeting to discuss the measures in December.

Contact Christina Jedra at (302) 324-2837, cjedra@delawareonline.com or on Twitter @ChristinaJedra.

A timeline of the proposed process

Licenses & Inspections inspects the property and identifies any violations.

A written notice is mailed to the property owner advising the owner of the violations.

The property owner has 30 calendar days (generally) to correct the violations. (The commissioner may shorten the time for repairs if he determines that a shorter period is essential to protect health and safety.) The property owner may request additional time to make the repairs if needed.

The time period to correct violation begins when the notice is received by the property owner or posted on the property in violation.

If the property owner wishes to dispute the violation notice, the owner may appeal the notice to the commissioner of L&I within the time period stated on the notice. (This first level of appeal is new and provides an opportunity to resolve issues without a full hearing before the L&I Review Board. Currently, the property owner would directly appeal to the L&I Review Board.)

The commissioner has 30 calendar days to issue a written decision.

Enforcement action is stopped until the commissioner issues a decision on the appeal.

A property owner who is not satisfied with the commissioner’s decision may appeal to the city’s Board of License & Inspection Review.

This appeal must be made within five business days of the commissioner’s decision.

The property owner receives a hearing before the board.

Enforcement action is stopped until the board issues a decision on the appeal.

A property owner who is not satisfied with the board’s decision may appeal the matter to the court.

If the property owner is successful in his/her appeal, the matter is generally concluded. If the property owner is not successful with the appeal, the owner is required to correct the violation within the time period listed on the notice (or obtain an extension from L&I).

After the time expires to complete the repairs (including any requested extensions of time), L&I will re-inspect the property.

If the violations are corrected, no fine is assessed. The matter is concluded.

If the violations are not corrected within the time period given, the fine is assessed to the property owner. (Under the current code, a criminal summons would be issued at this point and the matter proceeds to court.)

A fine may be issued for every seven-day time period that the violation(s) remain uncorrected. (Under the current code, a fine may be assessed for each day the violation remains uncorrected.)

If a fine is not paid, it is an automatic lien on the property. If the fine is paid, there is no lien.

A lien for unpaid fines under this chapter (along with other unpaid fees/charges/taxes) may form the basis for a future sheriff sale of the property.

Source: Wilmington Mayor's Office

search_result.title: Purzycki unveils plan to 'stabilize' Wilmington's West Center City
search_result.text:
One of Wilmington's roughest neighborhoods will see a greater police presence, increased trash pickup and a crackdown on liquor stores and nuisance properties under a new "neighborhood stabilization program" announced by Mayor Mike Purzycki on Thursday.

The plan, one of Purzycki's campaign promises, aims to "improve the lives of citizens" and strengthen a defined area, the zone from Adams to Tatnall streets and Fourth to 10th streets.

"Too many of our neighborhoods have been plagued by poverty, joblessness, blight and crime," Purzycki said, but improvements need to start in one place. "If we spread ourselves thin and try to achieve everything, we achieve nothing."

West Center City is a bold choice, and an easier location could have been chosen, the mayor said. More than 1 in 10 parcels in the neighborhood is a registered vacant property, and dozens have been identified for sheriff sale, the city said. Property owners in the area owe the city $1.8 million in debt, the Mayor's Office said, and there are 885 unresolved code violations since 2015. The area is also one of the most violent in the city.

But revitalizing the area could have a major impact. The area is adjacent to Wilmington's downtown business district and sits against I-95 through which drivers enter the city. As part of the program, Purzycki will assign additional resources to the neighborhood including police officers, licenses and inspections personnel, sanitation workers, and parks and recreation staff.

The mayor did not say how many individuals would be assigned to the neighborhood stabilization zone or how much money is being invested in the effort.

According to the mayor, elements of the initiative include:

Reducing crime, the flow of drugs, gang activity, prostitution and other criminal behaviors.

Ensuring that liquor and convenience stores are not "contributing to neighborhood instability."

Reinstituting "pre-rental inspections" to make sure residences meet city code requirements.

Holding property owners accountable for the interior and exterior of their buildings and use the sheriff sale process if those who neglect their property or are in debt to the city.

Supporting property owners in good standing with the city's property facade program.

Implementing traffic flow changes to interrupt "those who travel too freely in the neighborhood to conduct illicit activities."

Assisting the West Center City Neighborhood Association.

Reducing trash on streets and enforcing related laws.

Increasing mental and physical health resources and other social services as needed.

Partnering with the Christina School District on education programs.

Mark Williams, a gym supervisor at the William "Hicks" Anderson Center who grew up in West Center City, said he's optimistic about the stabilization program and Purzycki.

"By making it look good, it makes people feel better," he said. "It makes you want to take care of it. Kids will be kids, be destructive, but someone will say, 'You can't tear this up,' and maybe they won't do it again. When it looks good, more people want to be here."

The mayor also announced the city will spend $1.3 million on upgrades to the Hicks Anderson Community Center, the only city-owned community center. Improvements include reroofing and repainting the facility; repairing leaking pipes; installing a new water treatment system in the swimming pool; installing new lockers; putting in a new gym floor; and replacing several heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems.

Purzycki acknowledged on Thursday there have been many previous attempts to improve West Center City.

The area, which used to feature manicured lawns and clean streets, declined decades ago after I-95 sliced the city in half and provided a pipeline for drugs and the 1968 riots caused lasting destruction.

In 2015, West Center City was Wilmington's most violent neighborhood, and a review by The News Journal showed that decades of revitalization plans hadn't stopped the area's decline.

In 1963, city and federal officials began planning for the West Center City Urban Renewal project. The more than $20 million project called for better code enforcement and consequences for absentee landlords, according to News Journal archives. It also sought to rehabilitate 800 homes and build 400 new ones in, attracting interest from private developers.

Ultimately, the program was defunded under President Richard Nixon’s administration, but not before the Wilmington Housing Authority had helped to dismantle and demolish West Center City. Hundreds of residents were relocated out of the area, but there weren’t enough affordable houses for them to return.

In April 1988, officials introduced the West Center City Initiative, which again set out to renovate vacant homes and step up code enforcement. Mayor Daniel Frawley announced the program on the 700 block of Madison St.

Almost 30 years later in the same location, Purzycki echoed his predecessors' plans.

But this time, he said, it will be different.

"These concentrated deployments have been tried before with little success and certainly almost nothing in the long term," he said. "I believe it's because we lost our resolve, our concentration, and we chase the next shiny object. The failing was not necessarily strategy but the execution and relentless follow-up. This is a mistake we're not going to repeat."

The mayor said the state of West Center City is driving businesses away and putting people in danger. He cited the case of a day care that fled the neighborhood after its fence was hit by bullets.

"We're not going to see that kind of thing happen again," he said.

STORY: Decades of revitalization plans haven't diminished violence

STORY: New Wilmington police chief prioritizing community policing

City Councilman Vash Turner said in past efforts, "money wasn’t going where it needed to go."

"History does not have to repeat itself," he said.

City Councilman Nnamdi Chukwuocha, whose father is the namesake of the Hicks Anderson Community Center, said the neighborhood he grew up in has a plan, and it just needs help reaching its goals.

"West Center City is a great place," Chukwuocha said in an impassioned speech. "It's a place I want to stay, not a place I move to because I have to. ... I encourage everybody, let's do our part. We can make a difference, I promise you."

Some city residents are skeptical.

"We tried all that before," said Raymond Buker, a 42-year-old city resident.

Buker said he would have liked the mayor to talk directly with people in the city's neighborhoods "who have no title," who are not community leaders. If he had, Buker said Purzycki would see Wilmington's problems stem from the home.

"The trash is inside, not outside," he said.

For the Rev. Derrick Johnson, Purzycki's plan sounds like gentrification.

"The very dilemma of violence in these communities is not directly dealt with," he said. "I believe his view is: Take the bad element out, refurbish the property and bring 'good citizens' in."

The neighborhood stabilization program has the support of several nonprofit and private entities that will serve on a working group to help implement the goals. Members include residents and representatives of local nonprofits, Wilmington City Council, the Delaware Office of Alcohol and Tobacco Enforcement, the state Department of Health and Social Services, the Delaware Contractors Association and almost every department in the city of Wilmington.

"We’re not just going to be doing enforcement and tearing things down," Purzycki said. "We want to build up our communities."

search_result.title: Wilmington seeks public help developing 10-year plan
search_result.text:
Note: This story has been updated to include the estimated cost of the city's consultant, Interface Studio LLC.

Wilmington is beginning a year-long effort to come up with a comprehensive plan that will guide development across the city for the next 10 years.

Officials are seeking public input for the plan, called Wilmington 2028, the city said in a news release.

Mayor Mike Purzycki said the plan will address current challenges and develop "a new vision for tomorrow."

"This will be a community-driven effort which I would like to see reflect the hopes and priorities of our citizens," he said in a statement. "This plan will guide future development, and shape where and why public and private investment dollars are spent to make Wilmington a stronger and more prosperous city over the next decade.”

The plan, managed by City Planning Director Herb Inden, is required by a Delaware law that states all municipalities must have a comprehensive plan in place that is reviewed and updated every 10 years.

The most recent plan on the city's website was adopted in 2003, updated in August 2009 and was certified by the state in 2010, the mayor's office said. It is accompanied by 11 neighborhood plans that provide the framework for setting land-use policy, the city said.

"The new comprehensive plan will combine all of the existing plans into one document that will better reflect the goals and aspirations of residents and city government for Wilmington’s future," the city's announcement said.

STORY: 'Significant enhancements' coming to Wilmington Council discretionary fund

STORY: CDC intervention plan for Wilmington teen violence lacks political will

The original comprehensive development plan was adopted between 1953 and 1959 by the Wilmington Planning Commission, according to the 2003 plan.

The city hired a Philadelphia-based urban design firm called Interface Studio LLC to assist with the effort. The company's contract and exhibits, obtained by The News Journal, show they will be paid an estimated $350,000.

The company began conducting initial interviews with "stakeholders" in mid-August, the city said.

The city is asking citizens to participate in an online survey that will "translate the vision, hopes, dreams, and priorities of our residents" into the city's guide: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/Wilmington2028.

The survey asks residents to rate their overall satisfaction and quality of life issues like safety, sense of community, affordability, commuting time, parks and recreation and housing.

The survey process will be followed by five public meetings to begin in late October and run through the end of November, the city said. In early 2018, focus groups will address specific issues and make recommendations. Preliminary recommendations will be submitted to the public for feedback in the spring of next year, the city said, and a draft of the new comprehensive plan will be shared with citizens in the summer of 2018.

The mayor and planning department selected a 21-member steering committee to review the initial findings of the projects' research phase and help guide public engagement and plan development phases. The group is scheduled to meet every other month to help oversee, guide and promote the plan.

search_result.title: Wilmington to choose 17 new red-light camera locations
search_result.text:
The new cameras, and the removal of some existing ones, bring the total number of red-light cameras to 44.

Drivers in Wilmington would face more $110 fines if proposed red-light cameras are installed in 17 new locations.

The city said it would increase its intersection surveillance "based on state-provided data on traffic accidents and violations within Wilmington," according to a budget summary released last week.

The effort will cost $200,000, the summary said, but will be "more than offset" by the estimated $1.5 million in fines the city will collect in the first six months of 2019.

The city has not yet determined where the cameras will go, the Mayor's Office said.

A state law passed in 2016 requires municipalities to have a safety-based reason to install red-light cameras in a given location.

The state Department of Transportation gave the city a list of 31 intersections that do not have cameras and where "high accident data is evident," said John Rago, Mayor Mike Purzycki's deputy chief of staff for policy and communications.

The location on the list with the highest red-light-related crash numbers is at Walnut and 11th streets, which saw 39 "red-light running crashes" from 2011 to 2015, according to a DelDOT report.

Most of the considered sites had much fewer crashes. A site at Delaware Avenue and Washington Street experienced five such crashes in that time period.

The city will verify DelDOT's data in the coming weeks and will choose 17 sites. Those locations will require approval from DelDOT, and then the city will determine on which corner of the intersections the camera will be placed, Rago said.

There are currently 34 red-light locations in Wilmington. The city plans to remove seven of them "where occurrences of running red lights have dropped over the past four years to a point where the intersections are safer than they were before cameras were installed," Rago said.

Some drivers are not happy about the additional cameras.

Wilmington resident Wayne Rutman, 53, said the cameras appear to be a method to collect money without the city increasing property taxes or reducing spending.

He has several driving-related concerns in the city such as people driving recklessly or speeding — but people running red lights isn't one of them.

"Is it a big problem that needs 17 new red light cameras?" he said. "The obvious answer is no."

The government should be careful about angering residents and visitors in a city that struggles to attract people as it is, said Bill Cushing, a 67-year-old Pike Creek resident who drives in the city often.

"Once a person gets a red-light camera ticket, they’re going to think twice about going in," he said.

The city may eliminate some existing cameras or move them to locations with higher recorded crash data, Rago said.

Ken Grant, AAA Mid-Atlantic's manager for government and public affairs, said the company supports efforts to make driving safer as long as revenue generation is a secondary motivation.

"Is there a safety need? If they can point to 20 intersections where there have been crashes or near misses or things that have posed a safety risk to other drivers, pedestrians and bicyclists, we would support a move to make those intersections safer," he said. "Absent that, we’d have to have more of a conversation."

search_result.title: Delaware 2024 election: Who is running for office?
search_result.text:
Even though elections are a year and a half away, statewide and local races are already heating up across Delaware.

Before U.S. Sen. Tom Carper shared that he won't be running for re-election in 2024, others had already announced their plans for the 2024 campaign − with some as early as last year.

In recent months, candidates vying for New Castle County executive and Wilmington city mayor have launched their respective campaigns, as well as a play for insurance commissioner. Matt Meyer also made his intentions formal in his governor's race announcement in early June.

As people launch various state and local campaigns for office in the coming weeks and months, stay up to date with us here at Delaware Online/The News Journal for a running list of all the respective candidates.

Dover veteran vies for Republican line in Congressional race

Donyale Hall, a 53-year-old veteran, business owner and mother of 10, said Tuesday she is seeking the Republican nomination for Delaware’s at-large U.S. House of Representatives seat.

Hall, a biracial African American woman from Dover who has run for political office before, said the platform she’s always run on resonates on any level.

She said she brings a “unique” perspective to the seat having served in the U.S. Air Force in support of Operation Desert Shield and Desert Storm; being a survivor of domestic violence; and overall understanding others who feel as though they have been forgotten or overlooked.

Hall also seeks to expand small business opportunities and improve the public education system.

“I feel I bring unique vantage points to the things that I feel are problematic with our government,” Hall said. “I’m just continuing to forge a pathway that provides opportunity for people.”

Carney considers mayoral run as Purzycki won't run for 3rd term

Wilmington Mayor Mike Purzycki, who easily won two terms as Delaware's largest city's mayor, announced Wednesday he will not seek a third term, citing his age and desire to spend more time with family.

RELATED:Carney expresses interest in Wilmington mayor after Purzycki announces he won't run in 2024

Purzycki saw a city undergo tremendous economic development, while also struggling with ongoing crime. He previously served as the longtime executive director of the Riverfront Development Corp., seen as one of the architects in the development of the Wilmington Riverfront, and served on New Castle County Council in the early 1980s.

Following the news of Purzycki not seeking reelection, Delaware Gov. John Carney said he is "seriously considering" running for the office.

"Tracey and I have lived in Wilmington for thirty years, and I care deeply about our city," he said on Wednesday. "While I am focused on serving as Delaware's Governor, it's something I'm seriously considering."

Hall-Long announces run for Delaware governor

Lt. Gov. Bethany Hall-Long has announced that she will run for governor in 2024.

Hall-Long, if elected, would be the state’s second female governor, following Ruth Ann Minner, who served in the early 2000s. She has spent two decades in public office.

BACKGROUND:Lt. Gov. Bethany Hall-Long announces 2024 run for governor. To face Matt Meyer in primary

“There’s work to do to improve access to health care, create good-paying jobs, protect our rights and strengthen our education system – and I’m up for the challenge, because when you give a nurse a job -- that job gets done,” Hall-Long said in her campaign announcement.

Gay announces bid for lieutenant governor

State Sen. Kyle Evans Gay, a Democrat representing North Wilmington, announced in late August the launch of her campaign for lieutenant governor, resulting in an even more competitive race for 2024.

Gay was elected to the legislature in 2020, when she flipped a Republican-held seat. The senator previously worked as deputy attorney general in the Delaware Department of Justice before going into private practice. Her campaign video, which featured her two young daughters, focused on parenting.

“Delaware families know that raising kids is hard work, and it’s harder when the deck is stacked against working parents and working people," Gay said in her campaign announcement. "It’s what drove me to run for the State Senate, where I worked to pass bills that make it easier for Delawareans to afford the basics and raise a family."

“Delawareans know we have a lot more work to do," she said. "That’s why I’m running for Lieutenant Governor: to make sure Delaware works for working people.”

Eugene Young to run for Congress

Eugene Young, director of the Delaware State Housing Authority, announced this summer that he is running for Delaware’s at-large U.S. congressional seat.

Young, who made the announcement in a campaign email, has been viewed as a rising star in Delaware politics for years. If elected, Young would be the first Black man to represent Delaware in Washington, D.C.

“I have a deep, abiding sense of commitment to the state and the people of this state because the state's done so much for me,” Young said in an interview. “So for me, it's about how I serve those men and women and families that make up this wonderful state.”

Blunt Rochester enters as front runner to U.S. Senate race

U.S. Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester, Delaware’s sole congresswoman, entered the 2024 U.S. Senate race Wednesday, June 21.

Blunt Rochester, if elected, would become the first Black Delawarean and the first woman to represent The First State in the U.S. Senate – and possibly the third Black woman ever in the country’s history.

READ:Lisa Blunt Rochester, Delaware's sole congresswoman, will run to fill Carper's Senate seat

This announcement by Blunt Rochester has been highly anticipated, following U.S. Sen. Tom Carper’s retirement announcement in late May. The senior senator publicly called on the congresswoman to run – admitting she probably should have done so years ago.

Colleen Davis to run to U.S. House seat

Colleen Davis, state treasurer, announced Wednesday, July 19, that she will run for Delaware’s at-large U.S. House of Representatives seat.

Davis, 43, was largely unknown in Delaware before she ran for treasurer in 2018, defeating Republican incumbent Ken Simpler. She is also one of the rare statewide elected Democrats from Sussex County.

READ:State Treasurer Colleen Davis enters race for Delaware's US House seat

“Raising three children here in Delaware,” Davis said in an interview, “ I think that we need more leaders in Congress who come from working-class situations as I did growing up.”

“And truly, I'm focused on fighting for families and keeping them safe and secure.

Sarah McBride announces historic bid for Congress

State Sen. Sarah McBride, the country’s highest-ranking transgender elected official, announced her candidacy Monday, June 26, to become Delaware’s next sole congresswoman.

McBride, if elected, would become the first trans person elected to federal office, catapulting the already nationally known politician to an even bigger stage. She would also be the youngest elected official Delaware has sent to Washington since President Joe Biden’s U.S. Senate win in 1972.

“It's clear that diversity in government is necessary for us to not just ensure we have a healthy democracy but also to truly deliver for people,” she said in an interview with Delaware Online/The News Journal.

READ:Sarah McBride announces run for US House seat to become first trans member of Congress

Retired U.S. colonel to run for lieutenant governor

Debbie Harrington, a retired U. S. Army colonel, will run for lieutenant governor in 2024.

The Middletown resident served in the Army for 25 years. In her retirement, she became an advocate for children with disabilities. Her daughter is visually impaired.

Harrington, who has run unsuccessfully for other elected offices, is a vice chair of the state Democratic Party, as well as a part of Delaware State University's Board of Trustees, according to her website.

She is also vice chair of the Middletown Police Advisory Board.

Dorsey Walker announces bid for lieutenant governor

Rep. Sherry Dorsey Walker, a Wilmington Democrat, has announced her candidacy for lieutenant governor.

Dorsey Walker, who officially entered the race on Juneteenth, would become the state’s first Black woman to serve in this role. The representative previously ran for this seat in 2016, coming second to now Lt. Gov. Bethany Hall-Long in the 2016 Democratic primary.

“As Lt. Governor I will continue to be a boots-on-the-ground advocate for all Delaware citizens,” she said in her announcement. “My decision to announce on Juneteenth is symbolic of the advancements made by people of color, women, and those who seek the freedom that comes with change for the advancement of all mankind.”

New Castle County Executive Matt Meyer becomes first to enter governor's race

New Castle County Executive Matt Meyer announced in early June that he will run for governor in 2024

Meyer, who has been county executive since 2016, previously worked as a school teacher, attorney, entrepreneur and economic development adviser for the U.S. State Department in Iraq. He didn’t have much government experience before leading the state’s largest municipal government, which has an annual budget of about $300 million.

READ:New Castle County Executive Matt Meyer becomes first to enter 2024 governor's race

He signaled in his announcement that health care, affordable housing and education will be key issues in his campaign, noting the state “needs to move with greater urgency to tackle” these problems. Meyer has also been a polarizing figure. He has frequently publicly sparred with the county’s police union, which supported his opponent during his bid for county executive reelection in 2020.

Familiar face Velda Jones-Potter launches Wilmington mayoral campaign

Former city treasurer Velda Jones-Potter announced her run for Wilmington mayor in March, launching the first mayoral campaign for the 2024 election in Delaware’s largest city.

Jones-Potter unsuccessfully ran for the city seat in 2020, trailing incumbent Mayor Mike Purzycki by just over 1,000 votes in the Democratic Primary. Purzycki captured 42.9% of the total vote, compared to Jones-Potter’s 35.6%. Former City Councilperson Justen Wright also vied for the Democratic nomination, garnering 21.5% of the vote.

The former city treasurer’s mayoral campaign touts a focus on making neighborhoods safer, empowering Wilmington residents and using city resources efficiently. Those efforts include:

Creating an Office of Neighborhood Development to work across city departments and ensure needs of all neighborhoods are met.

Collaborating with community and city public safety to address challenges in policing, fire and emergency services.

Improving the city hiring process to promote diversity and establishing policies that promote social justice and economic equity.

Creating policies to ensure fairness, accountability, and transparency in all transactions involving public funds.

Updating city facilities and infrastructure to implement smart-city technology and remove lead and other hazardous materials.

The campaign did not respond to a request for comment.

With Meyer gone, Marcus Henry, Karen Hartley-Nagle make play for New Castle County executive

Two familiar faces to New Castle County politics are vying for the County Executive race.

Democrat Marcus Henry, son of former Senator Margaret Rose Henry, began his campaign for county executive in April of last year.

Henry has over 20 years of experience in public service and has worked for the past three county executive administrations, including as the general manager of the county Department of Community Services under current executive Matt Meyer and a brief stint as the county’s economic development director.

He has publicly stated his intention to bring transparency to the position and ensure that the county remains “a safe and flourishing home for residents, and an attractive destination for visitors.”

The Marcus Henry campaign did not directly respond to a request for comment.

Karen Hartley-Nagle, current New Castle County Council President, announced her candidacy on March 24 of this year. She has served as council president for the past six years, with two left in her current term.

Hartley-Nagle previously served as a board member of Delaware Common Cause and the Coalition for Open Government and was a member of the New Castle County Board of Adjustment. She has publicly stated that as County Executive, her main focus would be on core services such as public safety, parks and recreation, libraries, land use and infrastructure.

Hartley-Nagle has come under scrutiny from her fellow council members in the past, and was under investigation for hostile work environment claims. As Council President she has focused on uplifting the county’s senior population and attracting business development to the area.

The Hartley-Nagle campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Candidate enters Insurance Commissioner's race

Kayode Abegunde, a member of New Castle County's Financial Advisory Council, launched his campaign for insurance commissioner.

Abegunde, a Democrat, previously lost in the primary to incumbent Trinidad Navarro, who has served in the role since 2016. The two will likely face off again in the primary. In his announcement, Abegunde said would "bring more insurance products" to Delaware and provide more options to veterans.

search_result.title: Former state labor secretary enters congressional race
search_result.text:
Jon Offredo, and Jonathan Starkey

The News Journal

The race to occupy Delaware's only seat in the U.S. House of Representatives is getting crowded.

Former state Secretary of Labor Lisa Blunt Rochester announced Monday night her intention to run for the at-large position.

“My career has been spent solving problems—from being a voice for working Delawareans as Secretary of Labor to serving as the lead human-resources professional for Delaware’s largest employer to helping seniors and people with disabilities get their Social Security benefits as a caseworker in a congressional office," she said in a statement.

Rochester was deputy secretary of the state Health and Social Services department from 1993 to 1998 and was the state's first African American labor secretary from 1998 to 2001. She then became the state's personnel director in 2001. Later, she became CEO of the Metropolitan Wilmington Urban League.

“I’m running for Congress because a lot of people in Delaware are doing their best, but they’re still hurting," Rochester said. "I’ve spent my career advocating for those without a voice in communities across Delaware and I want to continue that work in Congress to ensure that all Delawareans have greater opportunity to succeed.”

Rochester joins a field of four seeking the seat being vacated by Congressman John Carney, a Democrat, who is not running for another term as he campaigns for governor.

Seeking the Democratic nomination are state Sen. Bryan Townsend, of Newark, a lawyer at Morris James in Wilmington, and state Rep. Bryon Short, of Highland Woods, a small business owner and chairman of the Delaware House Economic Development Committee.

Delaware Rep. Bryon Short declares for Congress

State Sen. Bryan Townsend announces congressional bid

Republicans Hans Reigle, a former Wyoming mayor, and Rose Izzo, a conservative activist, also are running. They face a deep structural disadvantage in Delaware, where there are 125,000 more Democratic voters than Republicans.

The Democratic and Republican primaries are Sept. 13. The election is Nov. 8, 2016.

Carney has been in Congress since 2011.

Another possible candidate is Democrat Sean Barney, who is making calls to potential Democratic supporters as he explores a campaign.

Barney's congressional run would follow a disappointing campaign last year for state treasurer. He lost the November 2014 general election to Republican Ken Simpler by 10 percentage points, collecting 43 percent of the vote.

Barney said in a statement that he is seriously considering a campaign.

"I love my country. I fought for my country," said Barney, who served as a Marine in Iraq. "But in this country and this state that I love, we are leaving too many of our fellow citizens behind. I do not believe it is good enough to wring one’s hands and say Congress is broken, if you are not willing to do something about it. For that reason, I am listening to those who are encouraging me to run and giving it careful consideration."

In conversations with potential supporters, Barney is discussing how he would approach a congressional campaign.

"He seems to see a course that would lead him to a primary victory," said Mitch Crane, the Sussex County Democratic chairman who spoke recently with Barney.

With the congressional field growing on Monday, Townsend said that "new ideas and open dialogue are always welcome."

"But new candidates will not change what is at the heart of my campaign: building on my strong record of public service and presenting a vision for a Congress that reverses the many inequalities we see in our state and country," Townsend said.

search_result.title: New Mexico may elect historic all-female US House delegation
search_result.text:
Russell Contreras

Associated Press

RIO RANCHO, N.M. (AP) — New Mexico voters have a chance this year to send a historic all-female U.S. House delegation to Congress, no matter which party wins races.

And the state’s three congresswomen may be all women of color — another national milestone.

Women are seeking the Democratic and Republican nominations in all six of the state’s primary races for three congressional seats. In each of those races, at least one Latina or one Native American woman is running in her respective party’s primary contests in what has turned out to be some of the most diverse political battles in the county. The women candidates have been among the largest fundraisers in races and could be their party’s nominees.

New Hampshire in 2013 became the first state to have an all-female Congressional delegation (Sens. Jeanne Shaheen and Kelly Ayotte, and Reps. Ann McLane Kuster and Carol Shea-Porter), according to the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers University. Delaware’s lone member of the U.S. House, Democratic Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester, who is black, helped give the state the nation’s first all-female of color U.S. House delegation in 2017.

But New Mexico could wind up with the largest U.S. House delegation of women or women of color in the nation’s history. The state's population of about 2 million is 49 percent Hispanic and 9 percent Native American.

More:Joe Biden vowed to pick a woman VP. Some Democrats say she must be a woman of color

“This is unusual,” Jean Sinzdak, associate director of the Center for American Women and Politics, said. “A record number of women are running for House seats, so this is interesting.”

In New Mexico’s 3rd Congressional Democratic primary, for example, Yale University graduate and Stanford University-trained lawyer Teresa Leger Fernandez and former CIA operative Valerie Plame are among those running in a crowded field to represent the state’s northern region. Both are indicative of the area’s traditional Hispanic past (Leger Fernandez is Latina) and recent coastal liberal transplants (the Anchorage, Alaska-born Plame is white).

On the Republican side, Navajo Nation member and businesswomen Karen Bedonie is waging her campaign for the GOP nomination in isolation and amid a strict curfew aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19. Her campaign literature features her in traditional Navajo clothing, and she often mentions to voters that she’s a mother of eight.

The seat is open because Democratic U.S. Rep. Ben Ray Lujan is running for U.S. Senate.

The state’s 1st Congressional District is currently held by Democratic U.S. Rep. Deb Haaland, who was one of the nation’s first Native American congresswomen.

Retired police officer Michelle Garcia Holmes, who is Hispanic, is among three Republicans seeking the GOP nomination to challenge Haaland for the Democratic-leaning seat representing Albuquerque.

In the state’s southern 2nd Congressional District, oil executive Claire Chase and former state lawmaker Yvette Herrell are locked in a nasty, three-person contest for the GOP nomination. Chase is the first female chair of the New Mexico Oil and Gas Association, and Herrell is an enrolled member of the Cherokee Nation.

They are seeking to unseat Democratic Rep. Xochitl Torres Small, the granddaughter of Mexican immigrants and who grew up in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

More:Republican slugfest for U.S. House seat in New Mexico's 2nd district

Retired University of New Mexico political science professor Christine Marie Sierra, who has followed women in politics for years, said this moment has been building for decades in New Mexico.

“Women are now seen as viable candidates, and both parties in New Mexico are doing their part to recruit women to run for office,” Sierra said. “And what you see here is a reflection of the state’s diversity.”

According to the Center for American Women and Politics, 490 women have filed as candidates for U.S. House seats nationwide in 2020, a new record high.

That surpasses even the record-breaking 2018 midterm election, in which 476 women filed to run for House seats, the center found.

The numbers could grow because filing deadlines have yet to pass in around a dozen or so states.

Much of the surge in candidate filings is in Republican primaries across the country, the center said.

Women also are making gains in local elections. Last year, for example, Tucson, Arizona, voters elected Regina Romero, the daughter of farm workers, as the first Latina mayor in the city’s history.

Leger Fernandez said whatever happens in her election, she’s proud to be part of a chance to make history. As a two-year-old, she was in a coma with spinal meningitis. Doctors didn’t believe she would survive.

Her grandmother, Abelina Romero Lucero, prayed to La Virgen de Guadalupe and later made a pilgrimage to Mexico to ask the heavens to heal her granddaughter.

Leger Fernandez has pictured herself having a conservation with her late grandmother after winning her race.

“I know exactly what she’d say,” Leger Fernandez said. “She’d tell me, ‘I knew there was a reason La Virgen let you live.’ ”

search_result.title: Running for Congress, Lisa Blunt Rochester draws on experience
search_result.text:
Adam Duvernay

The News Journal

EDITOR'S NOTE: This is the second in a series of profiles on candidates running for Delaware's at-large congressional seat.

In China, Lisa Blunt Rochester told stories. On the campaign trail for Delaware's at-large congressional seat, she listens to them.

Flung far from her Wilmington upbringing, she was in a foreign land where customs were unusual and her reasons for being there revolved around the love of a man. But the words she put down on papers – stories written with and about other expatriates in Shanghai – matter to her as much today as then.

"I waited until my daughter was ready to go to college. Then I sold the house, sold the car and moved to China for love. While there, I had a chance to do something I always wanted to do, which was to write full time. I ended up writing a book about women who reinvented themselves. It's called 'Thrive,'" Blunt Rochester said.

"What I loved about that project, and it's kind of symbolic where I am now, is for many of us, whether it's people who lost their jobs or homes during the downturn or people who lost their children to gun violence and me losing my husband, we have to reinvent ourselves constantly," she said.

In 2014, her 10-year romance with her second husband, Charles Rochester, ended with his death. It left Blunt Rochester without her best friend at a time when she was becoming a new woman. When she came home, her next calling became clear.

"I came back and just looked around at our city. I looked at our state and our country and I kept hearing all these extremes. At that moment, I was all into my own grief and had to step out of that and say, 'You know what, I'm still here. I can still serve, and there's much to be done," Blunt Rochester said. "I had to actually start thinking about what the trajectory of my career has been."

Blunt Rochester is running for Delaware's at-large seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. She's a Democrat in a packed field, contending against State Sen. Bryan Townsend, U.S. Marine Corps veteran Sean Barney and accountant Mike Miller in the Sept. 13 primary. Hans Reigle is the Delaware Republican State Committee's pick for the seat. Rose Izzo is also running as a Republican.

The former state secretary of labor – the first black woman in Delaware to hold that position – is part of a political legacy in Wilmington. She was the third to join the congressional race, following Townsend and state Rep. Bryon Short, who left the contest in April, and she hopes a victory will hand her the first elected seat of her career.

Blunt Rochester has the support of current state Labor Secretary Patrice Gilliam-Johnson. The pair worked together as leaders in the Wilmington Urban League during what Gilliam-Johnson labeled a transitional period where Blunt Rochester made her presence an asset.

"When she came on board, we knew she had a strong work ethic," Gilliam-Johnson said. "She was the kind of person that when she put her mind to something she could really move an agenda forward."

STORY: US House candidates struggle to differentiate positions

STORY: Short drops out of congressional race, cites money

Going to Washington

Blunt Rochester brings index cards with her to campaign gatherings. She hands them out to those she meets and asks they write down on the cards the issues that matter most. The answers, she said, show some striking similarities.

"We did it with students. We've done it with young professionals. We did it with a group of residents in Middletown," Blunt Rochester said. "There are some things that are common themes."

She said she learned the value of hearing all sides of an argument as the state's personnel director when tough cuts and state employees' livelihoods often were at odds. Whether it was union leaders, department heads or elected officials, she said she found every side shared something in the human need to be understood.

"One of the hallmarks of leadership, for me, is listening. It's pivotal. Even in this campaign, what we're doing is listening, going out to different parts of the state and listening," Blunt Rochester said. "People in this country are ready for that. They want to be heard. We all want to be heard."

Improving educational attainment, criminal justice reform, the perception of cities like Wilmington where fears of gun violence may dissuade new residents and business from joining the community, how to get and keep employment – for Blunt Rochester the concerns in the community boil down to issues of wealth.

"When people have a good job, maybe they don't need mental health counseling because they have a purpose. When people have a good job, they can have a home that their kids can live in and that kid can go to school and learn, and then maybe there's not the connection to the criminal justice system," Blunt Rochester said. "So if nothing else, if you don't hear anything else I say, I want people to know when they elect me they're going to elect somebody who relates to them."

Blunt Rochester, 54, supports tax credits designed to help small businesses get off the ground. She wants a higher federal minimum wage and is behind a recent expansion of overtime rules. She wants inmates, veterans, young people and women to have better access to job readiness training.

Her campaign website calls for ending loopholes for purchasing firearms and rails against the National Rifle Association as complicit in "families attending funerals instead of graduations." Defunding Planned Parenthood, her website claims, is part of a Republican effort to "try and drag us back to the last century."

The Blunt-Bradley Report was a 2001 document, bearing Blunt Rochester's old name, which found "substantial issues to be addressed" concerning perceptions among minority troopers and employees of their place in the ranks of the Delaware State Police. The document was prepared while she served as secretary of labor for Gov. Ruth Ann Minner, who issued an executive order establishing new equal opportunity hiring standards in state government.

The report found DSP in "technical compliance" with the law but recommended evaluating the methodology for promotion within DSP, establishing better written disciplinary practices, expanding recruitment efforts, strengthening avenues of appeal for filing racial and sexual discrimination complaints and giving the state office of personnel a larger role in monitoring DSP.

"We're kind of like a microcosm of the rest of the country, which gives people hope if you can do things here maybe we can do things across the country," Blunt Rochester said. "On the issue of jobs, on the issue of education, on the issue of women's health and the wage gap, people want real solutions and I have a history of doing that collaboratively with other people in the state."

Though she's held government positions in the past, she's never needed voters before her bid to be Delaware's first congresswoman. According to Delaware State University political science professor Samuel Hoff, that kind of service isn't as important for winning elections as it once was.

"The old route to Congress has changed," Hoff said. "That gives those candidates hope over and above what it use to be."

Voters are generally depressed with the state of Congress and distrustful of those who've served in it, Hoff said, and the current cycle of politics favors those who successfully present themselves as outsiders. Even the influence of party has waned, he said, but he believes raising at least $500,000 is a threshold amount to taking a U.S. House seat.

Blunt Rochester put together contributions totaling $234,770 in the first quarter of the year, bringing her to a total of $385,193 since she started her run. But that total includes a $100,000 loan from her own pocket.

"That loan is money left to me, and that is me saying to people I'm committed to this, I've got skin in the game," Blunt Rochester said. "We have done a very good job of being good stewards of the money other people have given us. While others may have raised a little bit more – because we've stayed competitive – we also were good stewards and ended up with the most cash on hand the first quarter out and the second quarter out."

That's not an insignificant loan, Hoff said, and she'll be a long time paying herself back. As for the message she said she hoped to send, Hoff believes it'll be up to the voters to decide whether it's "a gimmick" or "a hail Mary desperation pass."

STORY: Former state labor secretary enters congressional race

STORY: Congressional candidates stake ground on gun rights

Big shoes

Ted Blunt, Blunt Rochester's father, brought his family in 1969 from Philadelphia to Wilmington to work for Peoples Settlement Association, a social services organization more than a century old.

"That was one of the inspirations for me doing this. Many of the major institutions that help support families are struggling, and that was the one that brought us to Delaware," Blunt Rochester said.

He started working at the community center there and eventually rose to lead the City Council as president, though he'd aimed higher with bids to be a state representative and lieutenant governor. Hoff followed Delaware politics even then and said the man had a "party boss reputation," meaning an active and potent career in a time when politics was tough.

Ted Blunt's legacy is rooted in education and the changes the state was going through during desegregation, Hoff said. Hoff identified him as a man of civic service and said he has no doubts that long career made an impact on his daughter.

"That's something Lisa has followed," Hoff said. "That certainly rubbed off, that commitment to service."

Another of Blunt Rochester's role models was Jim Gilliam, a leader at the Wilmington Urban League. Gilliam considered Blunt Rochester a person he could trust during tough conversations and was one of her advocates for leadership, according to his daughter, Patrice Gilliam-Johnson.

"She has the state and the community in Delaware at the forefront of her interests," Gilliam-Johnson said. "I have seen her in numerous capacities be clear about what her goals and objectives are."

For Blunt Rochester, Gilliam's influence was foundational. She said she strives to live the inspiration he gave her.

"He used to say, 'Get off your duff.' That was one of his sayings. Don't just talk about the problems, do something. To have strong mentors like that really was important," Blunt Rochester said. "When I came on at the Urban League, it really was a time of transition because he was transitioning out of the organization and we were trying to figure out, in an environment where it's difficult to raise money for non-profits, at a time where you have to be relevant, how do we do that? Part of that was research and understanding what's happening in our neighborhoods."

Contact Adam Duvernay at (302) 324-2785 or aduvernay@delawareonline.com.

An earlier version of this article should have identified Lisa Blunt Rochester as the first black woman in Delaware to serve as state secretary of labor. It has been corrected.
